tables.opal.tasks:
1. Overview

The tasks table captures user-level task execution details across the workflow system. Each row represents an individual task assigned to a user, its status, due date, completion date, and variance (delay or early completion). This table is fundamental for workflow execution tracking, performance monitoring, and auditing who did what and when.

It is highly useful for:

  • Workflow automation & orchestration

  • Task performance analysis (e.g., variance, overdue tasks)

  • Workflow health checks

  • Responsible person assignment logs

2. Key Fields

Field Name

Type

Description

lineId

INTEGER

The lineId (foreign key) from the product table linking the task to a SKU.

role

STRING

The role of the person responsible for this task (e.g., Category Assistant, Project Manager).

userDisplayName

STRING

Full name of the user assigned to the task.

email

STRING

Email of the user responsible.

taskName

STRING

Name of the task (often includes stage and responsible role).

taskStatus

STRING

Current status of the task (e.g., ACTIVE, COMPLETE, ROLLBACK).

assetVersion

STRING

Version of the asset involved in the task (if applicable).

taskCreationDate

STRING

Timestamp when the task was created.

taskDueDate

STRING

Deadline for the task.

taskExecutionDate

STRING

Actual completion date (null if not completed).

approvalStatus

STRING

Approval outcome (if applicable) for tasks requiring approvals.

variance

FLOAT

Time variance between due date and execution date (in days). Positive = delayed, Negative = early completion.

3. Sample Query

sql

4. Usage Instructions

Workflow Monitoring

  • Track task-level workflow statuses (ACTIVE, COMPLETE, ROLLBACK).

  • Use variance to identify late or early task completions.

Role and User Analysis

  • Identify which users or roles have the most tasks assigned.

  • Detect potential workload imbalances across teams.

Process Control

  • Detect stuck tasks where taskStatus = 'ACTIVE' and taskDueDate < CURRENT_DATE().

  • Perform SLA (Service Level Agreement) monitoring.

Typical Joins

sql

  • This join allows you to enrich tasks with product information.

5. Notes

  • Some tasks may lack taskExecutionDate if not yet completed.

  • variance only meaningful when both taskDueDate and taskExecutionDate are present.

  • approvalStatus might be null for tasks that don't require approvals.

6. Dependencies

Related Tables:

  • product: Links via lineId to identify which product (SKU) the task is related to.

  • digital_assets : May link indirectly via assetVersion if the task is asset-related.

7. Additional Details & Query Tips

Get all overdue tasks:

Average variance per role:

sql

Count of tasks by status:

sql

Tasks completed early:

tables.opal.vw_npd:
1. Overview

The vw_npd view provides summarized commercial and forecasting data for New Product Development (NPD) SKUs. It is primarily used for high-level performance tracking of forecasted and actual sales, GP (Gross Profit) performance, and volume metrics for each NPD article.

This view helps commercial teams, supply chain planners, and category managers to:

  • Monitor NPD progress.

  • Compare forecasts vs. actuals.

  • Analyze performance across delivery teams and sub-categories.

2. Key Fields

Field Name

Type

Description

article

STRING

SKU or Article number (unique per product).

delivery_team

STRING

Assigned delivery team for the product.

sub_category

STRING

Sub-category of the product for classification.

released_date

STRING

Planned or actual release date of the SKU.

forecasted_sales

NUMERIC

Expected sales (in $AUD) for the SKU.

forecasted_GP

NUMERIC

Expected gross profit (in $AUD).

forecasted_GP_perc

NUMERIC

Forecasted gross profit percentage.

actual_sales

NUMERIC

Actual sales achieved to date.

actual_sales_meet_forecast

NUMERIC

Indicator flag (1/0) if actual sales met or exceeded the forecast.

annual_volume

NUMERIC

Expected annualized volume for the SKU.

projected_volume

NUMERIC

Projected sales volume from the latest projection.

NPD_filtering

STRING

NPD-specific filter tag (typically always 'NPD').

last_modified_date

STRING

Last update timestamp for this record in the view.

3. Sample Query

sql

4. Usage Instructions

Commercial Performance Monitoring

  • Compare forecasted_sales and actual_sales to track how well an NPD is performing financially.

  • Use forecasted_GP_perc to assess the planned margin.

  • actual_sales_meet_forecast helps flag SKUs that hit or miss the forecast.

Range and Delivery Team Analysis

  • Analyze sales forecasts and volumes at sub-category or delivery team levels.

  • Identify underperforming or outperforming NPDs.

Trend Reporting

  • Use released_date to group and report NPDs by launch period.

Filtering for Active NPDs

sql

5. Notes

  • actual_sales, actual_sales_meet_forecast and annual_volume might be 0 for SKUs that have not yet launched or collected sales.

  • actual_sales_meet_forecast is a simple flag and does not indicate by how much the forecast was exceeded or missed.

6. Dependencies

Related Tables:

  • product: Used for detailed product-level attributes if joined via article as the article number usually corresponds to product.articleNumberSKU.

  • project: Connects indirectly to the project-level metadata if you link via the product table.

tables.opal.tier_records:
1. Overview

The tier_records table is a consolidated view combining both project-level and product-level data, joining product.lineIdParent with project.lineId. This table enables users to view all relevant information (project milestones, product milestones, assigned roles, statuses, and workflow progress) in a single table.

It is primarily used for:

  • Generating project and SKU-level combined reports.

  • Milestone tracking across projects and products.

  • Facilitating end-to-end workflow analysis.

  • Providing a base for dashboards, workflow monitoring, and operational insights.

2. Key Fields

Identifiers

3. Sample Query

Find SKUs with delayed artwork upload

sql 'COMPLETE'; ]]>

Find all SKUs under a given project

View project and product milestone side by side

sql

4. Usage Instructions

  • For Full Project-SKU Reporting
    Always use tier_records when you need project-level and SKU-level information in one dataset.

  • For Role Assignments
    Use assigned roles fields to identify who is responsible for each milestone (roles may exist at both project and SKU levels).

  • For Workflow Milestone Tracking
    tier_records contains key milestone dates for common activities such as:

    • KickOff meetings

    • Concept Development

    • Design Briefs

    • Artwork Uploads

    • First Production Samples

    • Launch Activities

    • Post Launch Reviews

  • Join Hints
    This table is already denormalized; you do not need to join product and project tables manually when working with this.

5. Notes

  • lineIdParent = lineId of project

  • lineId = lineId of SKU

  • Always check if a field is NULL before assuming it's applicable, as some milestones may only exist at one level (project or SKU).

  • Many milestone fields have suffixes like _Due, _Actual, _Milestone, _Sent, _Submitted.

6. Dependencies

Related Tables:

  • project : Source for project-level data

  • product : Source for SKU-level data

  • business_process : Process structure

  • attributes : Tier and attribute configuration metadata

7. Additional Details & Query Tips

Understanding Structure

  • tier_records is designed as a flattened view combining both project and product data, allowing for easy consumption without additional joins.

  • Fields prefixed with Assigned, Upload, Confirm, Complete, Due, Actual, Sent, Submitted often represent workflow milestones and status tracking for either the project or the SKU.

Naming Conventions

  • Fields with _Project suffix usually indicate project-level information.

  • Fields with _SKU suffix are SKU-specific fields.

  • Fields without a suffix are typically common between both levels.

Analyzing Timelines

  • You can easily create Gantt charts, timeline reports, or delay trackers using milestone fields like:

    • KickOffMeetingDue, KickOffMeetingActual

    • DesignBriefDue, DesignBriefActual

    • ArtworkUploadDue2, ArtworkUploadActual2

    • LaunchDateDue2, LaunchDateActual2

    • PostLaunchReviewDue2, PostLaunchReviewActual2

Filtering Example

sql

Find projects without any linked SKUs

sql

Find overdue project milestones

sql

Aggregation Example

Count of SKUs per project

sql

Recommended Analysis Ideas:

  • Build full SKU Lifecycle reports directly from tier_records.

  • Develop workflow completeness checks (detect missing or overdue milestones).

  • Enable cross-team responsibility tracking by using the assigned roles columns.

  • Generate critical path dashboards using milestone sequences.

tables.opal.attributes:
1. Overview

The attributes table serves as a metadata repository describing available attributes used within the business processes, mainly for supporting configuration, user interfaces, and workflow setups.

It is not used for direct project analysis or reporting, but rather to document which fields exist in the operational project tables such as project, product .

2. Key Fields

field name

mode

type

description

attributeId

NULLABLE

INTEGER

Unique identifier for each attribute

attributeName

NULLABLE

STRING

Name of the attribute

tierIndex

NULLABLE

INTEGER

Attribute's position or level in the process

businessProcessId

NULLABLE

INTEGER

Identifier for the associated business process

businessProcessTierId

NULLABLE

INTEGER

Identifier for the tier within the process

3. Sample Query

sql

4. Usage Instructions

This table is primarily used for:

1) Workflow and System Configuration

  • Acts as a dictionary of attributes available to configure project and product workflows.

  • Defines which fields, inputs, or options are available based on businessProcessId, businessProcessTierId, and tierIndex.

  • Supports dynamic generation of user interfaces, workflow screens, and automation rules.

2) Joining with Project and Product Tables

  • businessProcessId and businessProcessTierId are keys to join with:

    • project.businessProcessId / businessProcessTierId

    • product.businessProcessId / businessProcessTierId

This enables:

  • Retrieving the list of attributes relevant to a specific project or product.

  • Building tier-based UI or validations dynamically.

Example Join:

sql

3) Filtering for Tier or Process Specific Attributes

  • Find attributes only for a specific business process:

sql

  • Find attributes used for a particular tier of a process:

sql

Typical Usage Scenarios

  • Workflow rendering for project or product forms.

  • Validating that all attributes are correctly configured in the process tiers.

  • Supporting data validation, UI generation, and automated task setups.

Important:

  • This table is not for direct analysis (e.g., counts, trends, business KPIs).

  • It is for structure definition, enabling smooth configuration of the project and product workflows.

  • Always combine this table with project or product when you need to know where and how the attribute is used.

5. Notes

  • Not suitable for analysis or project tracking directly.

  • Only useful as metadata to describe the structure of other operational tables.

  • Some attribute names may lack detailed business context without external documentation.

6. Dependencies

Related Tables:

  • business_process : This table uses as foreign key for tierIndex, businessProcessId and businessProcessTierId

7. Additional Details & Query Tips

  • For a quick list of attributes relevant to process 3:

    • SELECT attributeName FROM <project.dataset.attributes> WHERE businessProcessId = 3;
